fields.description:
When an issue key is entered in a comment using the 'XXXX-1234' syntax, it's highlighted and causes the issue pop-up to be displayed in Crucible.

When it's entered using a link 'https://jira.atlassian.com/XXXX-1234' only the issue key part of the link is highlighted, but it no longer works as an issue key (doesn't cause the popup to appear, instead directly navigating the browser).
fields.summary: Inconsistent JIRA issue key linking in comments
force project key format on DB level

fields.description:
Script crucible.py should look for current directory  firstly and then if none found it should look upwards the directory tree.


in case nested repositories it find wrong repository root.
fields.summary: Review CLI Tool should look for repository at current directory firstly

fields.description: When creating a review and adding a branch as content, it would be useful to save the last used "branch from" or allow this parameter to be set to a default branch.
fields.summary: The ability to set a default "branched from" when creating a Branch Review

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Executing the {{/rest-service/reviews-v1/filter/allClosedReviews}} REST call with a large amount of reviews is very slow. In some instances, this can take hours to complete.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Execute the {{/rest-service/reviews-v1/filter/allClosedReviews}} against a large instance.

h3.Workaround
Use further filters in order to not select every review created.
fields.summary: allClosedReviews REST Review Filter is Slow

fields.description: It would be really helpful if when comments become hidden because new changes are added, that there is a way to quickly see all the hidden comments. Even better, a button to see all the hidden comments within its original context.
fields.summary: See hidden comments
Spurious 'Reply doesn't exist.' warnings
Trying to render a very long URL in comment causes StackOverflow

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
After using REST API for changing user name all the reviews that associated with the old username (say the user is a reviewer, author or moderator) are no longer visible to the new user name until a Crucible re-index is performed.

h3. Suggested Solution
Add a REST API to perform the Crucible re-index.
 
h3. Workaround 
Perform the Crucible re-index from UI.
fields.summary: Add REST API for Crucible re-index

fields.description: It would be good to have the ability to either remove a due date or have a check box that makes the due date indefinite. Currently if you try to remove all date and time entries when editing a review, the information reappears when saved.
fields.summary: Make the due date of a review indefinite

fields.description:
Provide a new smart commit that allows to mark the associated commit as reviewed by a specific review.

Use cases:
- pre-commit reviews where the content has been reviewed already, and the committer wants to associate the review with the commit
- DVCS commits that were reviewed and then rebased - the commit ids are different, so they wouldn't be marked as reviewed, but a review does in fact exist
fields.summary: Allow marking commits as reviewed via smart commmit

fields.description: When you search from browser (client-side) with Ctrl+F on Firefox under Windows - Crucible prevent the browser from scrolling review page. It happens when reviewing files and try to search something inside them.
fields.summary: Ctrl+F doesn't scroll and find inside review under Firefox

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
In the review coverage report, the current percentage of reviewed code is the sum of the percentage of code with completed reviews, and the percentage of code that is in review. There should be a separate percentage to show code that has a completed review attached to it.

h3. Suggested Solution
Add a separate percentage to the report to show code that has completed reviewed associated.
fields.summary: Review Coverage Report: Show Percentage of Completed Reviewed Code

fields.description:
h4. Steps to reproduce
# create review in crucible
# add content => attatchment
# add a file containing the % character
# in the review, click the attatchment containing the character
# click "Download revision #n"

If the filename starts with % the following error will be observed:
{quote}Your request was unable to be processed
org.eclipse.jetty.util.Utf8Appendable$NotUtf8Exception - Not valid UTF8! incomplete UTF8 sequence
Not valid UTF8! incomplete UTF8 sequence
You are running release CR3.8.1 FE3.8.1 (20150619131232 2015-06-19), please report your release number when reporting bugs.{quote}

If the filename contains the % character it will lead to an error 400 (Bad request).

h4. Expected behaviour
Attatchments should be downloadable whether they contain a % character or not.

h4. Proposed fix
"spechial" characters in URLs should be encoded properly, e.g. %25 instead of % and %20 instead of a blank character etc.
fields.summary: % character not encoded in filename, breaks download

fields.description:
In Crucible 3.7.0 and 3.8.0, I can reproduce the following behavior in Safari and Chrome web browsers:
1. Create a review comment highlighting several lines of source code.
2. Edit the comment and change the source highlight, click "Comment" to save the changes.
3. The comment disappears. 
4. Creating a new comment on the same range of source lines will briefly show the original comment. Reloading the page will show the comment again.
fields.summary: Comments on lines of code disappear in a  review when highlight lines are edited

fields.description:
h3. Summary

If you specify a {{linkid}} attribute in a {{link}} Web Item when developing a FishEye/Crucible plugin, the {{id}} attribute is not rendered in the HTML.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a plugin
# In {{atlassian-plugin.xml}}, create a web item such as:
{noformat}
    <web-item key="config-link" section="system.userprofile.tab">
        <link linkid="some_config_link">/plugins/servlet/myplugin-config</link>
        <label key="Configuration"/>
    </web-item>
{noformat}
# The {{id}} attribute is not rendered in the HTML.

h3. Expected Results

The {{id}} should be rendered when using {{linkid}} as per https://developer.atlassian.com/display/DOCS/Web+Item+Plugin+Module#WebItemPluginModule-LinkElements

h3. Actual Results
The {{id}} attribute is not rendered in the HTML.
fields.summary: Web Item Link Does Not Render Linkid

h2. Workaround
To mitigate the issue we may truncate large commit messages in the database by running following SQL query:
{code}
UPDATE cru_fr_detail
SET cru_value = SUBSTRING(cru_value, 0, 2000)
WHERE cru_name = 'comment' AND length(cru_value) > 2000
{code}

fields.summary: NPE on uploading a patch file

fields.description:
In Admin > Project Settings > Projects, it's possible to +edit+ Fisheye Content, but it's no longer possible to remove paths again.

You can click remove, but you can't save and if you visit the page again you'll see nothing has been removed.
fields.summary: edit "fisheye content" is broken

fields.description:
When plugin tries to check permissions or get review it is very slow despite thoe data was most probabl already retrieved from the server.

Eg. if plugin provides condition for web-items which checks permissions it decreases performance.

fields.description: When attempting to add Stash repositories from the Admin page, I get the error message: "Problem communicating with Stash: Illegal character in query at index 89: https://[our intranet stash address]/rest/api/1.0/repos?start=0&limit=500&xoauth_requestor_id=Jared Preston". fields.description:
The customer reported system hang with over 1 million log entries like in the following snippet:
{code}
...
2015-07-09 12:04:47,879 WARN  - FRXRevision 2787786 doesn't exist.
2015-07-09 12:04:47,880 WARN  - FRXRevision 2787788 doesn't exist.
2015-07-09 12:04:47,880 WARN  - FRXRevision 2787790 doesn't exist.
2015-07-09 12:04:47,881 WARN  - FRXRevision 2787792 doesn't exist.
2015-07-09 12:04:47,882 WARN  - FRXRevision 2787794 doesn't exist.
2015-07-09 12:04:47,882 WARN  - FRXRevision 2787796 doesn't exist.
...
{code}

The review history revealed there where over 1000 revisions first added and then removed and when email thread processed then it found that ADD notification but was unable  to process it (revision was removed) then skipped it *not marking it as processed*. That caused the same skipped ADD notification to be processed multiple times (> 1000x1000).
fields.summary: Removing revision from review may cause recipient notification processed multiple times

fields.description: Crucible services classes contain [search methods | https://docs.atlassian.com/fisheye-crucible/latest/javadoc/com/atlassian/crucible/spi/services/SearchService.html#searchForReviewsByJiraKey(java.lang.String)] that could be used to retrieve reviews by associated Jira *issue key*. It would be great to have methods, that would be able to retrieve all reviews associated with certain Jira *project* (i.e. those with issue key belonging to proposed Jira project). Currently we have to iterate through all reviews and filter results manually, which turns out to cause performance problems.
fields.summary: Add possibility to search reviews by Jira project key

fields.description:
*Query:*
{code}
select revisions
from dir /
where on branch master and not reviewed
group by changeset
return csid, author, count(revisions), comment
{code}

*Curren Behavior:*
Currently the "where not reviewed" query will return all of the revisions not linked to a closed review, or ones that are not descendants of a revision attached to a closed review.

Therefore, if you have file.txt, which are in rev1, rev2, rev3 .. and only rev3 was added to a review, since rev1 and rev2 are descendants, they are going to be considered reviewed as well.
The only exception is if there are files in rev1 or rev2 that weren't touched in rev3. If those files have a HEAD revision in rev1 and rev2, those revisions will still be considered unreviewed.

*Undesirable Scenario:*
Having a file with 8 commits out of which the 6th commit was done by userA and the 8th commit was done by userB. Now userB wants to create a review of his code. UserB can't be asked to be responsible for the commits done by user A, so userB would make a review from the diffs between 7th to 8th commits. Diffs from 5th to 6th would still be considered reviewed, even though UserA has not created a review for their code. So, commit 6 should be reported as unreviewed (waiting for userA to do his job).

This is an issue if you want an EyeQL query to find out which revisions don't have a review in a branch as a necessary requisite for a merge. If UserB wants to merge and a query is run, it will show that all revisions have been reviewed, he's ready to go, which is not true, because UserA has not code-reviewed his changes yet.

The activity stream reports the true picture, it doesn't display a review icon next to the not reviewed revisions. 


*Conclusion*
The query should behave in the same way as the activity stream, otherwise the tool is reporting two different things depending of what reporting mechanism is used. 

If a revision is reviewed the linked revisions should not be shown as reviewed in the query or there should be a way to distinguish linked revisions from those that have a review created for them. An alternative would be to have a corresponding review icon next to those linked revisions so that it is consistent with the query.
fields.summary: Revisions EyeQL query considers reviewed conflicts with activity stream

fields.description:
It would be extremely handy to be able to hide/display the lines removed/added while keeping all the highlighting of the differences. The reason is that some diffs become so massive it's easier to read the new code by itself instead of in the diff. However, it is also helpful to know which lines have not changed in this instance. The side by side view doesn't fit on the screen at all and the unified diff becomes extremely hard to read with complex changes.

I was imagining a hotkey that could cycle the views or options in the "view" pull down.

I would imagine this would only be an option for the "unified diff" view as it doesn't make as much sense for the side-by-side diff (but it has its own problems as stated earlier).
fields.summary: Be able to hide/display lines removed or added but keep diff highlighting

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
As described on the [Email Notifications Not Being Sent|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fishkb/email-notifications-not-being-sent-691013114.html] article, Fisheye/Crucible may lose the connection to the network and when trying to send an email, the default settings allow it to wait indefinitely for a connection to the SMTP server. This connection then sits open and does not allow any new emails to be sent until the application is restarted.

This can be resolved by applying the {{Connection timeout}} and {{Timeout}} in the user interface (from the {{Administration >> Global Settings >> Server >> Mail Server >> Edit config}} user interface).

If the timeouts are set, the following can be found in {{config.xml}}, otherwise the parameters are omitted.
{code:xml}
<smtp ... connectionTimeout="1200" timeout="1200"
{code}

h3. Suggested Solution
Apply the suggested timeouts by default.

h3. Workaround
Manually apply the timeouts.
fields.summary: Set default timeouts for smtp

fields.description:
h4. +Scenario+
# A JIRA issue is mentioned in multiple FeCru commits
# From the issue's Development Panel, click Commits -> Create review for all commits
# The pop-up window populates the issue's description into the Objectives field

h4. +Suggestion+
The issue's description should not be populated into the Objectives field because:
{quote}
1. Nobody reads what's written there (there's nothing new anyway)
2. Because this section is always filled anyway, it discourages review creators to replace the auto-generated text with information that really adds some value to the review.
3. Last but not least: there's always this big ugly clump of text which is just no good.
{quote}
fields.summary: Create review for all commits should not populate JIRA issue description

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
In Crucible, if you leave a page while editing review details in the {{Edit Review Details}} window, your changes will be lost.

h3. Suggested Solution
A standard prompt should be shown to the user to let them decide if they really wants to leave without saving the changes.
fields.summary: Edit Reivew Details Dialog Should Prevent Reload When Changes Have Been Made
Customizable "My Reviews" in home dashboard

fields.description:
h3. Summary
If you have a patch containing diffs against multiple files, and there are only standard 2-line headers present, the diff is incorrectly parsed. Every other file will be skipped, but the contents of the missing files will be in the next file.

Example:

{noformat}
--- /tmp/test/file1.txt 1970-01-01 01:00:00.000000000 +0100
+++ /tmp/test2/file1.txt    2015-07-15 12:42:45.000000000 +0200
@@ -0,0 +1 @@
+hello world
--- /tmp/test/file2.txt 1970-01-01 01:00:00.000000000 +0100
+++ /tmp/test2/file2.txt    2015-07-15 12:42:52.000000000 +0200
@@ -0,0 +1 @@
+hello world 2
--- /tmp/test/file3.txt 1970-01-01 01:00:00.000000000 +0100
+++ /tmp/test2/file3.txt    2015-07-15 12:43:00.000000000 +0200
@@ -0,0 +1 @@
+hello world 3
--- /tmp/test/file4.txt 1970-01-01 01:00:00.000000000 +0100
+++ /tmp/test2/file4.txt    2015-07-15 12:43:08.000000000 +0200
@@ -0,0 +1 @@
+hello world 4
{noformat}

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Upload the above example file into a Crucible review as a patch.
# Only {{file.txt}} and {{file3.txt}} will be present. {{file3.txt}} will have the contents of {{file2.txt}}.

h3. Expected Results
All 4 files should be present, with the correct content.

h3. Actual Results
Only {{file.txt}} and {{file3.txt}} will be present. {{file3.txt}} will have the contents of {{file2.txt}}.

h3.Workaround
If you use GNU Diff for multiple files, it will include the command in the header, forming a 3 line header:

{noformat}
diff -ru --new-file /tmp/test/file1.txt /tmp/test2/file1.txt
--- /tmp/test/file1.txt 1970-01-01 01:00:00.000000000 +0100
+++ /tmp/test2/file1.txt    2015-07-15 12:42:45.000000000 +0200
@@ -0,0 +1 @@
+hello world
diff -ru --new-file /tmp/test/file2.txt /tmp/test2/file2.txt
--- /tmp/test/file2.txt 1970-01-01 01:00:00.000000000 +0100
+++ /tmp/test2/file2.txt    2015-07-15 12:42:52.000000000 +0200
@@ -0,0 +1 @@
+hello world 2
diff -ru --new-file /tmp/test/file3.txt /tmp/test2/file3.txt
--- /tmp/test/file3.txt 1970-01-01 01:00:00.000000000 +0100
+++ /tmp/test2/file3.txt    2015-07-15 12:43:00.000000000 +0200
@@ -0,0 +1 @@
+hello world 3
diff -ru --new-file /tmp/test/file4.txt /tmp/test2/file4.txt
--- /tmp/test/file4.txt 1970-01-01 01:00:00.000000000 +0100
+++ /tmp/test2/file4.txt    2015-07-15 12:43:08.000000000 +0200
@@ -0,0 +1 @@
+hello world 4
{noformat}

Having the {{diff}} line will allow it to be parsed correctly.
fields.summary: Multi-file Patch Upload With Only 2 Line Header Incorrectly Parsed

fields.description:
h3. Summary
In Crucible, If you change a permission scheme from one with a moderator to one without a moderator, reviews in state {{Waiting for Approval}} can no longer be transitioned.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a review that is in {{Waiting for Approval}} state.
# Change the permission scheme of the project to one without a moderator.
# It can no longer be transitioned.

h3. Expected Results
The user should be able to transition the review even though it is using the new permission scheme.

h3. Actual Results
Reviews in {{Waiting for Approval}} can no longer be transitioned.
fields.summary: Reviews in 'Waiting for Approval' State Cannot be Transitioned if Changed to a Permission Scheme without a Moderator

fields.description:
h3. Summary
If you use the {{Create review for all commits}} functionality from the JIRA development panel to create a review, with 3 or more commits, a newly added file may be marked as {{Modified}} in Crucible, which will place the sliders in the incorrect position, and instead show a diff.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create 3 commits linked to a JIRA issue, the first being a newly added file, and the other 2 being modifications to the added file.
# In JIRA, in the development panel, select {{Create review for all commits}}.

h3. Expected Results
A review should be created with the 3 revisions, and it should be marked as {{Added}}.

h3. Actual Results
A review is created with the 3 revisions, and it is marked as {{Modified}}.

h3.Workaround
Create the review manually in the Crucible UI.
fields.summary: "Create Review for All Commits" in JIRA Marks Added File as Modified in Review

fields.description:
During the creation of a branch review, having only a Crucible license in place, if the user clicks in the commit link presented while adding content to the review Crucible opens a page with a 404 Page Not Found error, since the page it's linking to is a FishEye page showing the diff for the commit.

*Steps to Reproduce*
# Have Crucible without a FishEye license.
# Create a new review, selecting {{Choose Branches}} in the {{Add content}} screen.

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

In the JIRA Development Panel, if there are multiple reviews attached to a JIRA issue, the review status shown is the most important in the following order:

REVIEW, APPROVAL, SUMMARIZE, REJECTED, CLOSED

Therefore, if there are 10 reviews linked, 9 are closed, and 1 is in review, it will show the status as {{REVIEW}}.

h3. Suggested Solution

We should adjust the number of reviews to show that {{x of y}} reviews are in {{STATE}}. Therefore, if there are 10 reviews, 9 are closed, and 1 is in review, it will show {{1 of 10 in REVIEW}}.
fields.summary: Number of Reviews in Certain State Should Be Shown in JIRA Development Panel

fields.description:
After creating a review of Crucible, the name (title) of the review will have a link (to the original JIRA issue) with header  "http://http://", which makes Chrome to parse a link with header "http//" and IE to parse a link with header "http//http://". Both browsers' parsing results are with wrong links.

Here is an example extracted from our internal Crucible review: [^test.html]
fields.summary: Invalid JIRA link in Crucible Review Name

fields.description:
The existing functions in Crucible to select text are a bit clumsy and nonstandard:
- click and drag selects source text at a per-line granularity and immediately opens a comment box on the selected lines
- Alt-click and drag selects the text displayed in the source window... but it includes both the line numbers and the text within the selection.

Alt-click is nonstandard and odd, and you don't know to do it unless you go out and search and find it in the documentation (https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CRUCIBLE016/2.3.1+Adding+Comments at the very end: "To select text on the page without adding a comment, hold down the Alt button while dragging the cursor.")

I would propose the following:

- Separate the line numbers and the source text in the HTML DOM, so it is not possible to copy the line numbers as part of the text.(which screws up text formatting) Allow users to *either* select lines via the line numbers portion of the display, or select text via the source text portion of the display.

- Either of the following behavior:
-- Drag-and-select line numbers to add a comment on lines; drag-and-select text of the lines should work normally and allow the web browser's copy function to work as it normally does. (I'd prefer this behavior)
-- Drag-and-select line numbers to add a comment on lines; drag-and-select text of the lines should pop up a pair of HTML buttons, one of which says "add comment", the other says "copy to clipboard"

Many people have commented on the odd behavior of Crucible's text selection, in the following issues, and it should really use something with a more natural user interface.

- https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CRUC-6103
- https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CRUC-6332
- https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CRUC-5919
- https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CRUC-1218
- https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CRUC-711
fields.summary: provide cleaner way of selecting lines for comments vs. selecting code in lines

fields.description:
I'm going to be assertive and marking this as a Bug rather than an Improvement.

Atlassian needs to support Markdown as a commenting markup language; it is the de facto markup language used online in many cases (bitbucket, github, reddit, stackoverflow) and honestly has a much cleaner design with fewer edge cases than the "wiki markup" used in Confluence and JIRA.

Stash comments allow the use of Markdown. We are considering using Crucible, only because of Stash's shortcomings... and now here I am reporting a shortcoming in Crucible that is addressed by Stash.
fields.summary: Missing option to use Markdown rather than the "wiki markup" format

fields.description:
I just noticed the following bug when I tried to add a changeset from a branch.

Steps to reproduce:
- add a repository A, limit the access to the repository to a group G
- create a project P, add A to P and make A the default repository of P when creating reviews
- add a repository B, do not limit the access
- create a review in P with a user U not in the restricted group G
- add a changeset from a branch: we have then an internal error because the user U does not have access to the default repository A, which is the one shown by default

Expected behaviour:
- when adding a changeset from a branch, the repositories that should be shown are the ones to which the current user has access to, not the default of the project.
fields.summary: Adding changesets from branch is broken when specific priviledges apply to repos

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When you shut Crucible down, sometimes it tries to issue a p4 login command. 

h3. Steps to reproduce
# Add a Perforce repository to FishEye
# Configure username and password
# Disable polling for the repository
# Enable debug in FishEye
# Shutdown FishEye

h3. Expected Results

FishEye shuts down without issuing a p4 login command.

h3. Actual Results

When the p4 login command is sent the following is seen in the logs; 
{noformat}
2015-06-25 11:44:26,499 INFO  [Thread-52 ] fisheye DefaultRepositoryManager-fullShutdown - shutdown p4repo
2015-06-25 11:44:26,510 DEBUG [Thread-52 ] fisheye P4CliUtils-dumpCommandLine - [localhost:1666//depot] Executing /home/daniele/perforce/bin/p4 -p localhost:1666 -C utf8 -u fisheye login 
{noformat}

h3. Notes
This occurs if the repository does not have a client allocated to it.
fields.summary: Crucible tries to login to Perforce repo at shutdown

fields.description:
This report contains few where significant improvement should be done.

Example load times from real FeCru instance:

Full dashboard load time: 42sec

# Review Statistics: loading all frxs into memory just to get the number of revisions per review (~8sec)
# Comment Volume: expensive to generate and not even shown by default (1sec)
# Review Status:  expensive to generate and not even shown by default (3sec)
# Defect Metrics: expensive to generate and not even shown by default  (1sec)
# var resultids (8sec)
# generating number of unread comments is expensive (i.e. checking permissions) (next to number of comments in Comments column) (10sec)
fields.summary: Project Review Dashboard is slow

fields.description:
h3. Summary
in FishEye/Crucible, when using smart commits, if there is more than one space following the project key, reviewers will not be assigned to the review.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Perform a commit with 2 spaces following the project key. i.e:
{noformat}
+review CR-MYKEY  @user1 @user2 @user3 JRA-zzzz #comment 
{noformat}
# The review will be created but reviewers will not be assigned; opening the review puts the owner into Edit Review Details.

h3. Expected Results
The reviewers should be added to the review, even if there are multiple spaces after the project key.

h3. Actual Results
The review is created, but reviewers will not be assigned.

h3.Workaround
Do not put multiple spaces between the project key and the first reviewer
fields.summary: Multiple Spaces after Project Key in Smart Commit causes reviewers not to be assigned

fields.description:
It would be nice if the Crucible could support configuring external File Comparison tools such as Beyond Compare. I believe that this can be done with SourceTree.

At my current employer we access Crucible from an on=premise instance view a web UI.  It is Version:3.5.4 Build:20140917115234 2014-09-17

I find the user experience of file comparison tools like Beyond Compare much better than the web UI experience. I understand that it would be difficult to added or view comments when using a 3rd party tool. However, for many files under review I don't need to view or add comments to it.  I would be happier if I could review the files in an external tool, but have to return to the Crucible UI to view or add comments.
fields.summary: Support for file comparison tools

fields.description:
When JIRA is set up so particular fields are mandatory, Crucible Issue Transitioning Plugin stops working, as it attempts to perform transition without mandatory fields. More over it does not inform the user transition failed, the only indication is that JIRA issue status remains as it was. In my environment: * "Fix version" field is set as mandatory on jira.atlassian.com * I'm trying to close issue from review page while closing the review * I am only presented Transition Issue and Choose Resolution fields, no Fix Version prompt, see !CITP-close-issue-wont-show-mandatory-fields.png|thumb! * the AJAX POST request https://fisheye.dev.internal.atlassian.com/plugins/servlet/reviewIssueTransitionsServlet gets 200 OK response, with the response indicating clearly the issue was NOT transitioned {code} { "issueStatus": "Open", "issueIcon": "https://jira.atlassian.com/images/icons/statuses/open.png", "issueTransitioned": false, "issueTransitionedWarning": "", "transitionsHtml": "
  • Start Progress
    Other transitions
    • Close Issue
    • Needs Triage
", "hasTransitions": true } {code}
fields.summary: Crucible Issue Transitioning Plugin should support mandatory fields

fields.description:
h3. Summary
In Crucible, if a review is moved into the {{Summarized}} state, it will no longer be shown on the review dashboard of the participants. It will still be shown on the review dashboard of the author under {{Inbox > Ready to Close}}

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Add a reviewer to a review.
# Move the review to {{Summarized}} state.
# Log in as the reviewer.
# The review is not shown on the reviewer's dashboard.

h3. Expected Results
The review should be shown under some section of the dashboard of all participants.

h3. Actual Results
The review is not shown on the participants's dashboard.
 
h3. Notes
This is the output when a review had been summarized but not closed. !bc59bc6032e460fa4b3386e498f62b2b.png|thumbnail!

h3.Workaround
The review must be visited directly through the URL.
fields.summary: Summarized Reviews not Shown on Review Dashboard for Participants

fields.description:
A commit message with "💜some message" as content will break Crucible.  (That's Unicode U+1F49C, as described on http://www.iemoji.com/view/emoji/37/people/purple-heart ).

When adding a commit with that message to a code review, I get the following error:

{quote}Server Error
Error 2
URL: /json/cru/CR-REIS-900/editRevisionsAjax/
A com.cenqua.crucible.hibernate.MaxRetriesReachedException was encountered
Unable to execute CrucibleRevisionCreator.createRevisionsInSeparateTransaction after 10 retries. Giving up
You are running release CR3.8.0 FE3.8.0 (20150427140019 2015-04-27), please report your release number when reporting bugs.
{quote}
This error is in the current version (3.8.0), and has been there since at least 3.1.1.
fields.summary: Crucible throws MaxRetriesReachedException on commit message with emoji

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Make a commit to a repository that does not have a commit message.
# Create a review.
# Select the changeset that does not have a commit message.
# A NullPointerException will be thrown.

h3. Suggested Solution
Set the title to {{Untitled}} in the case where no commit messages or comments are present.

h3. Workaround
# Create a review.
# When the window pops up to allow you to add content, select {{Done}}. to dismiss it.
# Set a review title manually by selecting {{Untitled}}.
# You can now add content with no commit messages.
fields.summary: NullPointerException When Creating a Review Where Latest Changeset Has No Commit Message

fields.description:
h3. Summary
FishEye/Crucible has log4j warning during startup.

This warning can be safely *ignored*.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
Start FishEye/Crucible 3.8
In {{fisheye.out}}
{noformat}
log4j:WARN No appenders could be found for logger (com.amazonaws.jmx.spi.SdkMBeanRegistry).
log4j:WARN Please initialize the log4j system properly.
log4j:WARN See http://logging.apache.org/log4j/1.2/faq.html#noconfig for more info.
{noformat}

h3. Expected Results
It shouldn't have the warning
fields.summary: log4j cannot find log appenders for amazonaws

fields.summary: Add option to ReviewCreator plugin to allow start reviews in different states

fields.description:
I think it is very nice if Crucible can support PDF file. I used PDF Pro version to Peer Review documents, and i think it is very good.
Moreover, you can easily convert Word, Excel, PPT to PDF for Reviewing.

PS: Sorry for my bad English
fields.summary: Support PDF Documents
Commit messages with an issue key preceded by a dash are not visible in JIRA development panel, despite having perforce job set

fields.description: If you're scrolled to the top of a review, clicking on a file in the review will automatically scroll the browser window down so that the review title and other options are hidden. This can be problematic on smaller file as it unnecessarily scrolls to the bottom of the page and hides information that could be displayed if there is enough screen real estate. The option for auto scrolling should either be able to be toggled or smart enough to only scroll if the file is large enough to need it.
fields.summary: Improve review header behavior for small files

fields.description: Per the attached screenshot, the file name is displayed in the Review History web interface, however per the corresponding attached CSV file, the file name is not provided.
fields.summary: CSV report does not display file name

fields.description: The "Date" column displays the UTC time instead of local system time.  In the attached screenshot, you can see the last change made at 10:39am.  In the corresponding CSV file, the "Date" column shows 15:39.
fields.summary: CSV report timestamps should include timezone info

fields.description:
The CSV file generated from a review does not show the added reviewer's name in the "New Value" column after adding a reviewer to a review.

In the example image attached reviewHistory-4.jpg, you can see that the user "test2" has been added as a reviewer, however in the export file reviewHistory-4.csv, the "New Value" cell is blank for the associated row.
fields.summary: CSV report does not display reviewer's name when added to a review

fields.description:
As a reviewer, I would like to track which of my comments have been addressed before I mark my review as "Complete".

When I get a satisfactory reply to one of my comment or that I see a new version of the file which answers my comment in a satisfactory manner, I would thus mark my own comment as resolved.
Once I've marked all my comments as resolved, I would then "Complete" the review.

This would be useful on large reviews. especially if there was a way to filter my comments that are resolved vs those that are not.
Currently, I have to look at each file one by one, find back all my comments to know if they were all answered. Painstakingly long on each iteration until I'm fully satisfied and can mark my review as "complete".

This could be summarized as a similar functionality to the resolution of in-line comments in Confluence 5.7+
fields.summary: Resolve my own comments

fields.description:
I Already asked in your Forum if this feature already exists: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/15295377/answers/15296826

The export function in Crucible generates a List of findings for every source file. But without the corresponding line number of the findings, this list is almost useless. 

Can you add the exact location of every finding to the review report?
fields.summary: Add Line Numbers to Crucible Review Reports

fields.description:
HTR:

# Create a commit with a dash right before the issue key 'test fisheye - ISSUE-1'
# Create a commit without a dash right before the issue key 'test fisheye ISSUE-1'
# Open the development panel on a linked JIRA instance

Expected:
# Both commits should be visible

Actual:
# Only the commit without the dash before the issue key is visible

{panel}Note: space character (' ') padding does not matter. This commit message will also fail: 'test-fisheye-ISSUE-1'
{panel}
fields.summary: Commit messages with an issue key preceded by a dash character are not visible in the JIRA development status panel.

fields.description:
*Steps to reproduce:*
# Create two reviews, CR-1 and CR-2, and add any comment on them
# In the Review Dashboard, click the "Advanced Search" link down below in the left panel
# Type CR-1 in "Review PermaId" field, search, and it will show CR-1 (correct)
# Type CR-2 in "Review PermaId" field, search, and it will show CR-2 (correct)
# Type CR-3 (or any junk text like asdasd) in "Review PermaId" field, search, and it will show CR-1 and CR-2.

If the search does not find any results, it will list all reviews, which is completely misleading. 
It should say that no reviews were found instead.
fields.summary: Advanced Comment Search problems with Review PermaId
